name: NMS-801
keyboard: 720 keys, with 5 Function keys and 4 arrow keys
ports: RGB output to TV SCART plug, composite monochrome, 2 x joystick, Tape recorder
description:
The NMS-801 was one of the last MSX machine made by Philips.  This economical computer was a true MSX machine. The official MSX logo was although replaced on the case by the "MSX Compatible" mark because the MSX standard required a cartridge slot, which the NMS-801 had not.

The NMS-801 was only sold in Italy where it wasn't very successful because of its poor expansion capabilities. However, Philips used the same case, CPU and video chip to produce the NMS-3000 and 4000, two video terminals dedicated to the Italian Videotel network, a precursor to the Internet which enabled each Italian family to access large databases as well as sending messages to one another. 

Thanks to Juan Villa for all the pictures.

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> TOP COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote>The top cover holds the RGB video circuitry and the TV/UHF modulator.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NMS-3000</strong></font><br><blockquote>The NMS-3000 was actually a VideoText terminal using a 3 MHz Z80A CPU, 4 KB RAM, 32 KB ROM.<br> The keyboard looked like mechanical but was of poor quality.</blockquote>

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT. (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"A TO7 from Thomson fills the empty cells"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Christian Hart for this scan</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Compatible with you know who.<br> Equiped like nobody.<br> Priced like Amstrad".<br> <br> Single drive, monochrome monitor = 4997 FF + VAT<br> Double drive, monochrome monitor = 6290 FF + VAT<br> Single drive, colour monitor = 6890 FF + VAT<br> Double drive, colour monitor = 8190 FF + VAT<br> Single drive, 20 MB hard-disk, monochrome monitor = 9990 FF + VAT<br> Single drive, 20 MB hard-disk, colour monitor = 11890 FF + VAT</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> QL CATALOGUE #7</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPACT VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>Promotional picture; <br><br> <b>Diego Barizo</b> adds:<br> In the picture of the compact version of the TK3000, the joystick, a TRS-80 de luxe joystick, and the screen is quite similar to that of a flight simulator for the TRS-CoCo. Maybe they had one behind the monitor? <p class="petitgris">Roberto Isiri</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ACCOUNTING SYSTEMS A5 AND A7</strong></font><br><blockquote>Systems A5 and A7, presented in 1974, contributing significantly to shifting the focus towards the supply Olivetti computer. These machines have the characteristics of a real computer, and hence a discontinuity from the previous accounting and billing are mainly based on mechanical technology. The new machines meet the favor of the European market and in 1975 the Swiss magazine Information, which specializes in computer and office products, a dedicated their cover.<p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.storiaolivetti.it" target="_blank">http://www.storiaolivetti.it</a></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZEALAND AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> SEGA'S new hard keyboard and new hard disk drive, make Sega even harder to beat.<br> The very latest industry standard 3" diskettes store a massive 328K of information each desk, and operate at speeds far in excess of their older 5 1/4 inch counterparts. Sega's super control station will also enable you to connect to many other attachments such as business printers electronic typewriters even telephone moderns, through it's two additional I/0 ports, for RS232C and parallel interfaces. <br><br> Sega now boasts not only the most sophisticated and easy to learn basic language, the most incredible graphic capabilities, a sensational range of cartridge and cassette games, superb education and applications software written by and for New Zealanders, but also a very sophisticated, fast, small business system, with the state of the art Sega control station. Feel the difference, see the difference, compare the difference, and you too can enjoy the difference of Sega superiority.</font> <br><br> Notice that between numerous superlatives, the advertising agency mistook floppy disk for hard disk drive.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zealand</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SEMI-TECH BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Isn't this a stupid advert ?!<br> Look carefully at each face !</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZEALAND ADVERT  #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> Imagine a microcomputer with all the design savvy, ruggedness, and sophistication of the best minicomputers.<br> Imagine a microcomputer supported by dozens of interface, memory and processor option boards. One that can be Interfaced to an indefinite number of peripheral devices including dual floppy discs, CRTs, line printers, cassette recorders, video displays, paper tape readers, teleprinters. plotters, and custom devices.<br> Imagine a microcomputer supported by extensive software IncludIng Extended BASIC, DISK BASIC, DOS and a complete library of business, developmental, and Industrial programs.<br> ImagIne a microcomputer that will do everything a mini will do, only at a fraction of the cost.<br> You are imagining the Altair 8800b. The Altair 8800b is here today, and it may very welt be the mainframe of the 70's. <br><br> The Altair 8800b is a second generation design of the most popular microcomputer In the field, the Altair 8800. Built around the 8800A microprocessor, the Altair 8800b is an open ended machine that is compatible with all Altair 8800 hardware and software. It can be configured to match most any system need.<br> MITS' plug-In compatible boards for the Altair 8800b now include: 4K static memory. 4K dynamic memory, 16K static memory, multi-port serial interface, multi-port parallel interface, audio cassette record interface, vectored interrupt, real time clock, PROM board, multiplexer, AID convertor, extender card, disc controller and line printer interface.<br> MITS' peripherals for the Altair 8800b include the Altair Floppy Disc, Altair Line Printer, teletypewriters, and the soon-to-be-announced Altair CRT terminal. <br><br> Introductory prices for the Altair 8800b are $840 for a kit with complete assembly instructions, and $1100 for an assembled unit. Complete documentation, membership into the Altair Users Club, subscription to "Computer Notes", access to the Altair Software Library, and a copy of Charles J. Sippi's Microcomputer Dictionary are included.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zealand </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ABORTED ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>One of the aborted advert campaigns for the 8048 was "Micromania".<p class="petitgris">Thomas Fischer</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (DECEMBER 1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"At 12 years old, Nicolas discovered he was the terror of the aliens"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert for the Micromachine 4000 but a picture of the Micromachine 2000 and 3000 is inserted for reference...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Tim_K for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a small advert from a french reseller "Vectron". The ad is dated november 1984 and the EXL-100 is sold for 3240fr. <br><br> The title says : "The french answer" </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHARLIE CHAPLIN #5</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ONTEL ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT JUNE 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said: <br><br><font color="#666666"> With NEC's PC-8800 personal computer, you don't have to ask yourself which comes first, the hardware or the software.<br> It's designed to be uncompromising in both areas. So you come first. In the office or at home.<br> The hardware gives you your choice of 8-bit or 16-bit processors, 5 1/4" or 8" disk drives and standard green or high resolution color monitor.<br> The software includes advanced, user friendly programs for all types of banking, accounting and business management. Plus free WordStar word processing, and MailMerge, Multiplan spread sheet, BASIC (two versions), and CP/M... </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RUSSIAN ADVERT - PAGE 2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Taras Ponomarev for this advert</p></blockquote>

emulator.name: openMSX - The MSX emulator that aims for perfection.
emulator.description: This new MSX emulator can reproduce, among many other MSX, MSX2and  MSX2+ machines, both Panasonic Turbo-R models. Be sure to get the catapult frontend and the system roms from FUNET.
